channel.title: Athletics Talk Now
channel.description:
Athletics Talk Now is the leading Oakland A's podcast on the web. Founded by Dale Tafoya in 2010, AAD has hosted some of the most prolific voices in the baseball world. Celebrating the storied past and future of the A's franchise through podcasts, blogs, and social media, AAD is devoted to providing fans with high quality content, engaging commentary and thought-provoking interviews.
About Dale Tafoya
Dale Tafoya is author of Bash Brothers (Potomac Books, 2008) and has followed Oakland A’s baseball for thirty years. His work has appeared in the Oakland Tribune, Contra Costa Times, Orlando Sentinel, Modesto Bee, The Source, and Beckett Baseball Card Monthly. In addition to his writing credits, Tafoya has been a guest on ESPN Radio, FOX Sports, Cumulus Media and Comcast Sports. Tafoya resides in the San Francisco-Bay Area.
channel.itunes:author: Dale Tafoya
channel.itunes:summary: Dale Tafoya is author of Bash Brothers, and has followed the Oakland A’s for 25 years. His work has appeared in the Oakland Tribune, Contra Costa Times, Orlando Sentinel, Huntsville Times, & Modesto Bee. In addition to his writing credits, he has been a guest on ESPN Radio, FOX Sports, Cumulus Media & Comcast Sports. Tafoya resides in the East Bay.

item.title: Athletics Talk Now: Adam Olsen and Tyler Bleszinski (Podcast No. 128)
item.description: In podcast No. 128, Adam Olsen and Tyler Bleszinski join Dale Tafoya and explain how they took their passion for the A's and launched something special.

item.title: Athletics Talk Now: Ken Korach, Susan Slusser and Billy Beane (Podcast No. 127)
item.description: In podcast No. 127, A's radio voice Ken Korach, A's beat writer Susan Slusser and A's GM Billy Beane join Dale Tafoya. Enjoy.
item.itunes:subtitle: In podcast No. 127, A's radio voice Ken Korach, A's beat writer Susan Slusser and A's GM Billy Beane join Dale Tafoya. Enjoy.

item.title: Athletics Talk Now: Bruce Jenkins (Podcast No. 126)
item.description: In podcast No. 126, former A's beat writer and longtime columnist Bruce Jenkins joins Dale Tafoya in a special podcast entitled, "Oakland A's Baseball Through the Years." Jenkins talks Charlie Finley, Billy Martin, Tony La Russa and the A's future in Oakland.
item.itunes:subtitle: Oakland A's Baseball Through the Years (1968-Present)

item.title: Athletics Talk Now: Billy Beane (Podcast No. 125)
item.description: In podcast No. 125, A's GM Billy Beane remembers the grittiness of the 2006 A's, the last A's team to reach the American League Championship Series. Enjoy.
item.itunes:subtitle: In podcast No. 125, A's GM Billy Beane remembers the grittiness of the 2006 A's, the last A's team to reach the American League Championship Series. Enjoy.

item.title: Athletics Talk Now: My Story with Seth Honeycutt (Podcast No. 124)
item.description: In our debut segment of "My Story" our newest blogger Seth Honeycutt reveals how his love affair with the A's began and his favorite moments in franchise history. Enjoy.
item.itunes:subtitle: In our debut segment of "My Story" our newest blogger Seth Honeycutt reveals how his love affair with the A's began and his favorite moments in franchise history. Enjoy.

item.title: Athletics Talk Now: Dave Stewart, Rick Tittle, Joe Stiglich and Melissa Lockard (Podcast No. 123)
item.description: In podcast No. 123, A's legend Dave Stewart, 95.7 The Game's Rick Tittle, CSN Bay Area's Joe Stiglich and Oakland Clubhouse's Melissa Lockard provide us with our offseason A's fix. Enjoy.
item.itunes:subtitle: In podcast No. 123, A's legend Dave Stewart, 95.7 The Game's Rick Tittle, CSN Bay Area's Joe Stiglich and Oakland Clubhouse's Melissa Lockard provide us with our offseason A's fix. Enjoy.

item.title: Athletics Talk Now: Ken Korach (Podcast No. 122)
item.description: In podcast, No. 122, A's Radio Voice Ken Korach on the aftermath of writing his book, Holy Toledo, the ALDS and the A's Stadium Dilemma.
item.itunes:subtitle: In podcast, No. 122, A's Radio Voice Ken Korach on the aftermath of writing his book, Holy Toledo, the ALDS and the A's Stadium Dilemma.

item.title: Athletics Talk Now: Terry Steinbach (Podcast No. 121)
item.description: Description: In podcast No. 121, former A's catcher Terry Steinbach on A's early postseason exit, the glory days, '89 earthquake, and playing under the Haas family. Enjoy.
item.itunes:subtitle: Description: In podcast No. 121, former A's catcher Terry Steinbach on A's early postseason exit, the glory days, '89 earthquake, and playing under the Haas family. Enjoy.

item.title: Athletics Talk Now: Dave Stewart (Podcast No. 120)
item.description: In podcast No. 120, A's great Dave Stewart on A's playoff fever, facing Roger Clemens, the Oakland Coliseum, and his relationship with ownership.
item.itunes:subtitle: In podcast No. 120, A's great Dave Stewart on A's playoff fever, facing Roger Clemens, the Oakland Coliseum, and his relationship with ownership.

item.title: Athletics Talk Now: Andy Dolich (Podcast No. 119)
item.description: In podcast No. 119, former A's executive Andy Dolich on "Billy Ball" the "Bash Brothers" and why the A's will stay in Oakland. Enjoy.
item.itunes:subtitle: In podcast No. 119, former A's executive Andy Dolich on "Billy Ball" the "Bash Brothers" and why the A's will stay in Oakland. Enjoy.

item.title: Special Report: Robert Gammon
item.description:
Robert Gammon, a reporter for the East Bay Express, reported today that “Oakland is in the driver’s seat to keep the A’s.” In podcast #28, he talks about his discoveries.

Please note: This update was recorded at 2:00 p.m. PST. Since then, an MLB spokesman told the San Francisco Chronicle that “despite reports, the stadium committee had not completed the study nor made any recommendations.”
item.itunes:subtitle: Robert Gammon, a reporter for the East Bay Express, reported today that “Oakland is in the driver’s seat to keep the A’s.” In podcast #28, he talks about his discoveries. Please note: This update was recorded at 2:00 p.m....

item.title: Stadium Debate 2010
item.description:
In this stirring debate, Newballpark.org's Jeffrey August articulates why San Jose is a better home for the A's. Oakland's Jorge Leon explains why the organization is better off staying put. Both die-hard A's fans, they stroll to the plate, pull out their notebooks, and passionately state their case. 

The opinions expressed do not necessarily represent the views of AthleticsAfterDark.com.
item.itunes:subtitle: In this stirring debate, Newballpark.org's Jeffrey August articulates why San Jose is a better home for the A's. Oakland's Jorge Leon explains why the organization is better off staying put. Both die-hard A's fans, they stroll to the plate, pull out...

item.title: THE ROAD TO OAKLAND #2 (with Melissa Lockard)
item.description: Scout.com’s Melissa Lockard has the pulse of the Oakland A’s minor league system. Covering the organization since 2004, she chronicles the journey of each prospect on their way to Oakland. The Road to Oakland, hosted by Melissa and Dale, is a quarterly segment on AthleticsAfterDark.com. In this podcast, Melissa talks the Arizona Fall League, Michael Choice, Grant Green and why flame-throwing relievers, Fautino De Los Santos and Henry Rodriguez could be the next version of the “Nasty Boys.”
item.itunes:subtitle: Scout.com’s Melissa Lockard has the pulse of the Oakland A’s minor league system. Covering the organization since 2004, she chronicles the journey of each prospect on their way to Oakland. The Road to Oakland, hosted by Melissa and Dale,...

Join us every month for The A’s Report on AthleticsAfterDark.com.

item.title: Remembering the Big Three with Mychael Urban
item.description: Perhaps one of the most dominant trios of starting pitchers in franchise history, Mark Mulder, Tim Hudson and Barry Zito hurled the A’s to four consecutive playoff appearances, beginning in 2000. The driving force behind the Moneyball A’s of the early millennium, the Big Three brought playoff fever back to Oakland for the first time since 1992. CSNBayArea.com’s Baseball Insider Mychael Urban, a former A’s beat writer for MLB.com and author ofACES: The Last Season on the Mound with the Oakland A’s Big Three, remembers their reign with Dale Tafoya.
item.itunes:subtitle: Perhaps one of the most dominant trios of starting pitchers in franchise history, Mark Mulder, Tim Hudson and Barry Zito hurled the A’s to four consecutive playoff appearances, beginning in 2000. The driving force behind the Moneyball A’s...

item.title: A's Report #4 (with David Feldman & Casey Pratt)
item.description: The A’s Report, host Dale Tafoya, Emmy Award-winning producer Casey Pratt, and A’s historian David Feldman
item.itunes:subtitle: The A’s Report, host Dale Tafoya, Emmy Award-winning producer Casey Pratt, and A’s historian David Feldman

item.title: Back in the Day: Dave Stewart
item.description: Born in Oakland, California, Dave Stewart played eight seasons (1986-1992 & 95) with the Oakland A’s, and was one of the most dominant pitchers of his era. From 1987-1990, Stewart reeled off four consecutive 20-win seasons, going a combined 84-45 during that span. Known for his intimidating stare and devastating forkball, Stewart hurled the A’s to three straight World Series appearances, sporting a career record of 8-0 in five American League  Championship Series. Acknowledged by A’s fans as “Stew,” he speaks with Dale Tafoya about his years in Oakland, why the A’s only won one World Championship in his heyday, and why the San Jose A’s just doesn’t sound right.
item.itunes:subtitle: Born in Oakland, California, Dave Stewart played eight seasons (1986-1992 & 95) with the Oakland A’s, and was one of the most dominant pitchers of his era. From 1987-1990, Stewart reeled off four consecutive 20-win seasons, going a combined...

item.title: Back in the Day: Remembering Rickey with Monte Poole
item.description: Rickey Henderson is arguably the greatest Oakland A’s player of all time, and a first-ballot Hall-of-Famer. In his 14 seasons with the A’s, he played for three owners and six managers, eventually fueling the franchise to a world championship in 1989. On his Hall of Fame plaque in Cooperstown, New York, it reads: “Faster than a speeding bullet, scored more runs, and stole more bases than any player in history. Combined power, plate discipline, flair, and an uncanny ability to electrify crowds.” Long-time Oakland Tribune columnist Monte Poole delves into Henderson’s career with Dale Tafoya, and explains why he was the greatest athlete he’s ever covered.
